back:
Apply \(u\)-substitution:

\[ \begin{align*} u &= x^3 + 1 \\ du &= 3x^2 \, dx \end{align*} \]

Then:

\[ \begin{align*} \int 3x^2 \sqrt{x^3 + 1} \, dx &= \int \sqrt{u} \, du \\ &= \frac{2}{3} u^{\frac{3}{2}} + C \\ &= \frac{2}{3} (x^3 + 1)^{\frac{3}{2}} + C \end{align*} \]

Apply \(u\)-substitution:

\[ \begin{align*} u &= -x^2 \\ du &= -2x \, dx \\ -\frac{1}{2} du &= x \, dx \end{align*} \]

Then:

\[ \begin{align*} \int xe^{-x^2} \, dx &= -\frac{1}{2} \int e^u \, du \\ &= -\frac{1}{2} e^u + C \\ &= -\frac{1}{2} e^{-x^2} + C \end{align*} \]

Apply \(u\)-substitution:

\[ \begin{align*} u &= x^2 + 1 \\ du &= 2x \, dx \\ \frac{1}{2} du &= x \, dx \end{align*} \]

Then:

\[ \begin{align*} \int \frac{x}{(x^2 + 1)^2} \, dx &= \frac{1}{2} \int \frac{1}{u^2} \, du \\ &= -\frac{1}{2} \frac{1}{u} + C \\ &= -\frac{1}{2} \frac{1}{x^2 + 1} + C \end{align*} \]

front:
\[ \int e^{\cos x} \sin x \, dx \]

Solve the integral.
back:
Apply \(u\)-substitution:

\[ \begin{align*} u &= \cos x \\ du &= - \sin x \, dx \\ - du &= \sin x \, dx \end{align*} \]

Then:

\[ \begin{align*} \int e^{\cos x} \sin x \, dx &= - \int e^u \, du \\ &= - e^u + C \\ &= - e^{\cos x} + C \end{align*} \]

Apply \(u\)-substitution:

\[ \begin{align*} u &= e^x + 1 \\ du &= e^x \, dx \end{align*} \]

Then:

\[ \begin{align*} \int \frac{e^x}{e^x + 1} \, dx &= \int \frac{1}{u} \, du \\ &= \ln |u| + C \\ &= \ln (e^x + 1) + C \end{align*} \]

Apply \(u\)-substitution:

\[ \begin{align*} u &= x^2 + 1 \\ du &= 2x \, dx \\ \frac{1}{2} du &= x \, dx \end{align*} \]

Then:

\[ \begin{align*} \int \frac{x}{x^2 + 1} \, dx &= \frac{1}{2} \int \frac{1}{u} \, du \\ &= \frac{1}{2} \ln |u| + C \\ &= \frac{1}{2} \ln (x^2 + 1) + C \end{align*} \]

Apply \(u\)-substitution:

\[ \begin{align*} u &= \cos x \\ du &= - \sin x \, dx \\ - du &= \sin x \, dx \end{align*} \]

Then:

\[ \begin{align*} \int \frac{\sin x}{1 + \cos^2 x} \, dx &= - \int \frac{1}{1 + u^2} \, du \\ &= - \tan^{-1} u + C \\ &= - \tan^{-1} (\cos x) + C \end{align*} \]

Apply \(u\)-substitution:

\[ \begin{align*} u &= \sin x \\ du &= \cos x \, dx \end{align*} \]

Then:

\[ \begin{align*} \int \cos(x) \sin(\sin(x)) \, dx &= \int \sin(u) \, du \\ &= - \cos(u) + C \\ &= - \cos(\sin(x)) + C \end{align*} \]

Apply \(u\)-substitution:

\[ \begin{align*} u &= \ln x \\ du &= \frac{1}{x} \, dx \end{align*} \]

Then:

\[ \begin{align*} \int \frac{\ln x}{x} \, dx &= \int u \, du \\ &= \frac{1}{2} u^2 + C \\ &= \frac{1}{2} (\ln x)^2 + C \end{align*} \]

Apply \(u\)-substitution:

\[ \begin{align*} u &= \ln x \\ du &= \frac{1}{x} \, dx \end{align*} \]

Then:

\[ \begin{align*} \int \frac{1}{x \ln x} \, dx &= \int \frac{1}{u} \, du \\ &= \ln |u| + C \\ &= \ln | \ln x | + C \end{align*} \]

Apply \(u\)-substitution:

\[ \begin{align*} x &= u - 1 \\ u &= x + 1 \\ du &= dx \end{align*} \]

Then:

\[ \begin{align*} \int \frac{x}{\sqrt{x + 1}} \, dx &= \int \frac{u - 1}{\sqrt{u}} \, du \\ &= \int \frac{u}{\sqrt{u}} \, du - \int \frac{1}{\sqrt{u}} \, du \\ &= \int u^{1/2} \, du - \int u^{-1/2} \, du \\ &= \frac{2}{3} u^{\frac{3}{2}} - 2u^{\frac{1}{2}} + C \\ &= \frac{2}{3} (x + 1)^{\frac{3}{2}} - 2(x + 1)^{\frac{1}{2}} + C \end{align*} \]

Apply \(u\)-substitution:

\[ \begin{align*} u &= x^2 \\ du &= 2x \, dx \\ \frac{1}{2} du &= x \, dx \end{align*} \]

Then:

\[ \begin{align*} \int \frac{x}{1 + x^4} \, dx &= \frac{1}{2} \int \frac{1}{1 + u^2} \, du \\ &= \frac{1}{2} \tan^{-1}(u) + C \\ &= \frac{1}{2} \tan^{-1}(x^2) + C \end{align*} \]

Apply \(u\)-substitution:

\[ \begin{align*} x &= u + 1 \\ u &= x - 1 \\ du &= dx \end{align*} \]

Then:

\[ \begin{align*} \int (x + 1) \sqrt{x - 1} \, dx &= \int (u + 2) \sqrt{u} \, du \\ &= \int (u \sqrt{u} + 2 \sqrt{u}) \, du \\ &= \int (u^{\frac{3}{2}} + 2 u^{\frac{1}{2}}) \, du \\ &= \int u^{\frac{3}{2}} \, du + 2 \int u^{\frac{1}{2}} \, du \\ &= \frac{2}{5} u^{\frac{5}{2}} + \frac{4}{3} u^{\frac{3}{2}} + C \\ &= \frac{2}{5} (x - 1)^{\frac{5}{2}} + \frac{4}{3} (x - 1)^{\frac{3}{2}} + C \end{align*} \]

Apply \(u\)-substitution after completing the square:

\[ \begin{align*} x^2 + 4x + 8 &= (x + 2)^2 + 2^2 \\ u &= x + 2 \\ du &= dx \end{align*} \]

Then:

\[ \begin{align*} \int \frac{1}{x^2 + 4x + 8} \, dx &= \int \frac{1}{u^2 + 2^2} \, du \\ &= \frac{1}{2} \tan^{-1} \left( \frac{u}{2} \right) + C \\ &= \frac{1}{2} \tan^{-1} \left( \frac{x + 2}{2} \right) + C \end{align*} \]

Apply \(u\)-substitution:

\[ \begin{align*} u &= 1 + \sqrt{2x} \\ &= 1 + (2x)^\frac{1}{2} \\ du &= (2x)^{-\frac{1}{2}} \, dx \\ dx &= (2x)^\frac{1}{2} \, du \\ \end{align*} \]

Then:

\[ \begin{align*} \int \frac{1}{1 + \sqrt{2x}} \, dx &= \int \frac{1}{u} (2x)^\frac{1}{2} \, du, \quad (2x)^\frac{1}{2} = u - 1 \\ &= \int \frac{1}{u} (u - 1) \, du \\ &= \int \frac{u}{u} - \frac{1}{u} \, du \\ &= \int du - \int \frac{1}{u} \, du \\ &= u - \ln |u| + C \\ &= (1 + \sqrt{2x}) - \ln(1 + \sqrt{2x}) + C \end{align*} \]

Apply \(u\)-substitution:

\[ \begin{align*} u &= \sqrt{x} \\ du &= \frac{1}{2 \sqrt{x}} dx \\ &= \frac{1}{2 u} \, dx \\ dx &= 2u \, du \end{align*} \]

Then:

\[ \begin{align*} \int e^{\sqrt{x}} \, dx &= 2 \int u e^u \, du \\ &= 2 u e^u - 2 e^u + C \\ &= 2 e^u (u - 1) + C \\ &= 2 e^\sqrt{x} ( \sqrt{x} - 1 ) + C \end{align*} \]

Apply \(u\)-substitution:

\[ \begin{align*} u &= \sqrt{x} \\ du &= \frac{1}{2 \sqrt{x}} \, dx \\& = \frac{1}{2 u} \, dx \\ dx &= 2u \, du \end{align*} \]

Then:

\[ \begin{align*} \int \frac{1}{1 + \sqrt{x}} \, dx &= 2 \int \frac{u}{u + 1} \, du \\ &= 2 \int \frac{u + 1 - 1}{u + 1} \, du \\ &= 2 \int 1 - \frac{1}{u + 1} \, du \\ &= 2 \left( u - \ln |u + 1| \right) + C \\ &= 2 \left( \sqrt{x} - \ln |\sqrt{x} + 1| \right) + C \end{align*} \]

Integrate by parts:

\[ u \, dv = uv - \int v \, du \] \[ \begin{align*} u &= \ln x & dv &= dx \\ du &= \frac{1}{x} \, dx & v &= x \end{align*} \]

Then:

\[ \begin{align*} \int \ln x \, dx &= x \ln x - \int x \frac{1}{x} \, dx \\ &= x \ln x - \int dx \\ &= x \ln x - x + C \end{align*} \]

Integrate by parts:

\[ u \, dv = uv - \int v \, du \] \[ \begin{align*} u &= (\ln x)^2 & dv &= dx \\ du &= \frac{2 \ln x}{x} \, dx & v &= x \end{align*} \]

Then:

\[ \begin{align*} \int (\ln x)^2 \, dx &= x (\ln x)^2 - \int x \frac{2 \ln x}{x} \, dx \\ &= x (\ln x)^2 - 2 \int \ln x \, dx \\ &= x (\ln x)^2 - 2 (x \ln x - x) + C \end{align*} \]

Apply trigonometric identity:

\[ \sin^2(x) = \frac{1 - \cos(2x)}{2} \]

Then:

\[ \begin{align*} \int \sin^2(x) \, dx &= \int \frac{1-\cos(2x)}{2} \, dx \\ &= \int \frac{1}{2} - \frac{1}{2} \cos(2x) \, dx \\ &= \frac{1}{2} x - \frac{1}{4} \sin(2x) + C \end{align*} \]

Apply trigonometric identity:

\[ \cos^2(x) = \frac{1 + \cos(2x)}{2} \]

Then:

\[ \begin{align*} \int \cos^2(x) \, dx &= \int \frac{1 + \cos(2x)}{2} \, dx \\ &= \int \frac{1}{2} + \frac{1}{2} \cos(2x) \, dx \\ &= \frac{1}{2} x + \frac{1}{4} \sin(2x) + C \end{align*} \]

Apply trigonometric identity:

\[ \sin^2(x) = 1 - \cos^2(2) \]

Then:

\[ \begin{align*} \int \sin^3(x) \, dx &= \int \sin^2(x) \sin(x) \, dx \\ &= \int (1 - \cos^2(x)) \sin(x) \, dx \\ \end{align*} \]

Apply \(u\)-substitution:

\[ \begin{align*} u &= \cos(x) \\ - du &= \sin(x) \, dx \end{align*} \]

Then:

\[ \begin{align*} \int (1 - \cos^2(x)) \sin(x) \, dx &= \int - (1 - u^2) \, du \\ &= \int u^2 - 1 \, du \\ &= \frac{1}{3} u^3 - u + C \\ &= \frac{1}{3} \cos^3(x) - \cos(x) + C \end{align*} \]

Apply trigonometric identity:

\[ \cos^2(x) = 1 - \sin^2(2) \]

Then:

\[ \begin{align*} \int \cos^3(x) \, dx &= \int \cos^2(x) \cos(x) \, dx \\ &= \int (1 - \sin^2(x)) \cos(x) \, dx \\ \end{align*} \]

Apply \(u\)-substitution:

\[ \begin{align*} u &= \sin(x) \\ du &= \cos(x) \, dx \end{align*} \]

Then:

\[ \begin{align*} \int (1 - \sin^2(x)) \cos(x) \, dx &= \int 1 - u^2 \, du \\ &= u - \frac{1}{3} u^3 + C \\ &= \sin(x) - \frac{1}{3} \sin^3(x) + C \end{align*} \]

Apply trigonometric identity:

\[ \sin^2(x) = \frac{1 - \cos(2x)}{2} \]

and

\[ \cos^2(2x) = \frac{1 + \cos(4x)}{2} \]

Then:

\[ \begin{align*} \int \sin^4(x) \, dx &= \int \left[ \frac{1 - \cos(2x)}{2} \right]^2 \, dx \\ &= \int \frac{1}{4} \left[ 1 - 2\cos(2x) + \cos^2(2x) \right] \, dx \\ &= \int \frac{1}{4} \left[ 1 - 2\cos(2x) + \frac{1}{2}(1 + \cos(4x)) \right] \, dx \\ &= \int \frac{1}{4} \left[ \frac{3}{2} - 2\cos(2x) + \frac{1}{2} \cos(4x) \right] \, dx \\ &= \int \frac{3}{8} - \frac{1}{2} \cos(2x) + \frac{1}{8} \cos(4x) \, dx \\ &= \frac{3}{8} x - \frac{1}{4} \sin(2x) + \frac{1}{32} \sin(4x) + C \end{align*} \]

Apply trigonometric identity:

\[ \cos^2(x) = \frac{1 + \cos(2x)}{2} \]

and

\[ \cos^2(2x) = \frac{1 + \cos(4x)}{2} \]

Then:

\[ \begin{align*} \int \cos^4(x) \, dx &= \int \left[ \frac{1 + \cos(2x)}{2} \right]^2 \, dx \\ &= \int \frac{1}{4} \left[ 1 + 2\cos(2x) + \cos^2(2x) \right] \, dx \\ &= \int \frac{1}{4} \left[ 1 + 2\cos(2x) + \frac{1}{2}(1 + \cos(4x)) \right] \, dx \\ &= \int \frac{1}{4} \left[ \frac{3}{2} + 2\cos(2x) + \frac{1}{2} \cos(4x) \right] \, dx \\ &= \int \frac{3}{8} + \frac{1}{2} \cos(2x) + \frac{1}{8} \cos(4x) \, dx \\ &= \frac{3}{8} x + \frac{1}{4} \sin(2x) + \frac{1}{32} \sin(4x) + C \end{align*} \]

Apply trigonometric identity:

\[ \sin^2(x) = 1 - \cos^2(x) \]

Then:

\[ \begin{align*} \int \cos^2(x) \sin^3(x) \, dx &= \int \cos^2(x) \sin^2(x) \sin(x) \, dx \\ &= \int \cos^2(x) (1 - \cos^2(x)) \sin(x) \, dx \end{align*} \]

Apply \(u\)-substitution:

\[ \begin{align*} u &= \cos(x) \\ - du &= \sin(x) \, dx \end{align*} \]

Then:

\[ \begin{align*} \int \cos^2(x) (1 - \cos^2(x)) \sin(x) \, dx &= \int - u^2 (1 - u^2) \, du \\ &= \int u^4 - u^2 \, du \\ &= \frac{1}{5} u^5 - \frac{1}{3} u^3 + C \\ &= \frac{1}{5} \cos^5(x) - \frac{1}{3} \cos^3(x) + C \end{align*} \]

Apply trigonometric identity:

\[ \cos^2(x) = 1 - \sin^2(x) \]

Then:

\[ \begin{align*} \int \sin^2(x) \cos^3(x) \, dx &= \int \sin^2(x) \cos^2(x) \cos(x) \, dx \\ &= \int \sin^2(x) (1 - \sin^2(x)) \cos(x) \, dx \end{align*} \]

Apply \(u\)-substitution:

\[ \begin{align*} u &= \sin(x) \\ du &= \cos(x) \end{align*} \]

Then:

\[ \begin{align*} \int \sin^2(x) (1 - \sin^2(x)) \cos(x) \, dx &= \int u^2 (1 - u^2) \, du \\ &= \int u^2 - u^4 \, du \\ &= \frac{1}{3} u^3 - \frac{1}{5} u^5 + C \\ &= \frac{1}{3} \sin^3(x) - \frac{1}{5} \sin^5(x) + C \end{align*} \]

Apply trigonometric identity:

\[ \sin(2x) = 2 \sin(x) \cos(x) \]

and

\[ \sin^2(2x) = \frac{1 - \cos(4x)}{2} \]

Then:

\[ \begin{align*} \int \sin^2(x) \cos^2(x) \, dx &= \int \sin(x) \sin(x) \cos(x) \cos(x) \, dx \\ &= \int \frac{1}{4} \left( 2 \sin(x) \cos(x) \right) \left( 2 \sin(x) \cos(x) \right) \, dx \\ &= \int \frac{1}{4} \sin(2x) \sin(2x) \, dx \\ &= \int \frac{1}{4} \sin^2(2x) \, dx \\ &= \int \frac{1}{8} \left( 1 - \cos(4x) \right) \, dx \\ &= \frac{1}{8} \left( \int dx - \int \cos(4x) \, dx \right) \\ &= \frac{1}{8} \left( x - \frac{1}{4} \sin(4x) \right) + C \\ &= \frac{1}{8} x - \frac{1}{32} \sin(4x) + C \end{align*} \]

\[
\begin{align*}
    \int \frac{1}{1 + \sin(x)} \, dx
    &= \int \left( \frac{1}{1 + \sin(x)} \right) \left( \frac{1 - \sin(x)}{1 - \sin(x)} \right) \, dx \\
    &= \int \frac{1 - \sin(x)}{1 - \sin^2(x)} \, dx \\
    &= \int \frac{1 - \sin(x)}{\cos^2(x)} \, dx \\
    &= \int \frac{1}{\cos^2(x)} - \frac{\sin(x)}{\cos^2(x)} \, dx \\
    &= \int \sec^2(x) - \tan(x) \sec(x) \, dx \\
    &= \tan(x) - \sec(x) + C
\end{align*}
\]

front:
\[ \frac{d}{dx} W(x) \]

Find the derivative of the Lambert \(W\) function.
back:
Use implicit differentiation:

\[ \begin{align*} W(x) e^{W(x)} &= x \\ \frac{d}{dx} \left( W(x) e^{W(x)} \right) &= \frac{d}{dx} x \end{align*} \]

Use the chain rule:

\[ \begin{align*} W(x) e^{W(x)} \cdot W'(x) + e^{W(x)} \cdot W'(x) &= 1 \\ W'(x) ( W(x) e^{W(x)} + e^{W(x)} ) &= 1 \\ W'(x) ( x + e^{W(x)} ) &= 1 \end{align*} \]

Since

\[ W(x)e^{W(x)} = x \implies e^{W(x)} = x/W(x) \]

Then:

\[ \begin{align*} W'(x) &= \frac{1}{x + e^{W(x)}} \\ &= \frac{1}{x + x/W(x)} \\ &= \frac{W(x)}{x W(x) + x} \\ &= \frac{W(x)}{x (W(x) + 1)} \end{align*} \]

front:
\[ \int W(x) \, dx \]

Find the anti-derivative of the Lambert \(W\) function.
back:
Apply \(u\)-substitution:

\[ \begin{align*} u &= W(x) \\ x &= u e^u \\ dx &= (u e^u + e^u) \, du \\ &= e^u (u + 1) \, du \end{align*} \]

Then:

\[ \begin{align*} &= \int W(x) \, dx \\ &= \int u e^u(u+1) \, du \\ &= \int e^u (u^2 + u) \, du, \quad \text{Integrate by parts} \\ &= (u^2 + u) e^u - (2u + 1) e^u + 2e^u + C \\ &= u u e^u - u e^u + e^u + C \\ &= x W(x) - W(x) + e^{W(x)} + C \\ &= x W(x) - W(x) + \frac{x}{W(x)} + C \end{align*} \]

front: The definition of the extreme value theorem (EVT).
back:
The extreme value theorem states that if a real-valued function \(f\) is continuous on the closed and bounded interval \([a,b]\), then \(f\) must attain a maximum and a minimum, each at least once.

That is, there exist numbers \(c\) and \(d\) in \([a,b]\) such that: \(f(c) \leq f(x) \leq f(d) \quad \forall x \in [a,b]\).

In simpler terms, a continuous function on a closed interval will always have a highest point and a lowest point.

The Rolle's theorem is a special case of the mean value theorem.

The Rolle's theorem states that if a function \(f(x)\) is:

  • Continuous on a closed interval \([a,b]\)
  • Differentiable on the open interval \((a,b)\)
  • \(f(a)=f(b)\) (the function has the same value at the endpoints)

Then there exists at least one point \(c\) in the open interval \((a,b)\) such that \(f'(c) = 0\).

Geometrically, this means if a continuous and differentiable curve starts and ends at the same height, there must be at least one point in between where the tangent line is horizontal (i.e., the slope is zero).

front: The definition of the mean value theorem (MVT).
back:
The mean value theorem is a generalization of Rolle's theorem.

The mean value theorem states that if a function \(f(x)\) is:

  • Continuous on a closed interval \([a,b]\)
  • Differentiable on the open interval \((a,b)\)

Then there exists at least one point \(c\) in the open interval \((a,b)\) such that the instantaneous rate of change (the derivative \(f'(c)\)) is equal to the average rate of change over the interval.

Mathematically, this is expressed as:

\[ f'(c) = \frac{f(b) - f(a)}{b - a} \]

The Rolle's theorem can be derived from the mean value theorem: if \(f(a) = f(b)\), then the right side of the mean value theorem equation becomes

\[ f'(c) = \frac{f(a) - f(a)}{b - a} = \frac{0}{b - a} \]

which means \(f'(c)=0\).

front: The definition of the intermediate value theorem (IVT).
back:
The intermediate value theorem states that if a function \(f(x)\) is continuous on a closed interval \([a,b]\), and \(L\) is any value between \(f(a)\) and \(f(b)\), then there exists at least one number \(c\) in the interval \([a,b]\) such that \(f(c)=L\).

Intuitively, if you can draw the graph of a function without lifting your pencil, and it goes from one y-value to another, it must pass through all the y-values in between.

An infinite sequence is an ordered and indexed list of numbers of the form

\[ a_1, a_2, a_3, \ldots, a_n, \ldots \]

denoted as

\[ \{ a_n \}_{n=1}^{\infty} \]

or simply

\[ \{ a_n \}. \]

Each number \(a_n\) is a term of the sequence.

The subscript \(n\) is the index variable of the sequence.

front: What are the different ways to define a sequence?
back:
An infinite sequence can be defined in various ways:

  • By listing terms \(\{ 2, 4, 6, 8, \ldots \}\).

  • By an explicit formula that defines the \(n\)-th term directly in terms of \(n\), \(a_n = f(n)\).

  • By a recurrence relation, a rule that defines a term based on previous terms in the sequence, \(a_n = f(a_{n-1}, a_{n-2}, \ldots)\).

TODO Add examples.

front: What is the limit of a sequence?
back:
A sequence \(\{ a_n \}\) converges to a real number \(L\) if for all \(\epsilon > 0\), there exists an integer \(N\) such that \(|a_n − L| < \epsilon\) if \(n \ge N\). The number \(L\) is the limit of the sequence and we write

\[ \lim_{n \to \infty} a_n = L \text{ or } a_n \to L. \]

In this case, we say the sequence \(\{a_n\}\) is a convergent sequence. If a sequence does not converge, it is a divergent sequence, and we say the limit does not exist.

front: What is the squeeze theorem for sequences?
back:
Consider sequences \(\{a_n\}\), \(\{b_n\}\), and \(\{c_n\}\). Suppose there exists an integer \(N\) such that \(a_n \le b_n \le c_n\) for all \(n \ge N\). If there exists a real number \(L\) such that

\[ \lim_{n \to \infty} a_n = L = \lim_{n \to \infty} c_n, \]

then \(\{b_n\}\) converges and

\[ \lim_{n \to \infty} b_n = L \]

A sequence \(\{a_n\}\) is bounded above if there exists a real number \(M\) such that

\[ a_n \le M \]

for all positive integers \(n\).

A sequence \(\{a_n\}\) is bounded below if there exists a real number \(M\) such that

\[ M \le a_n \]

for all positive integers \(n\).

A sequence \(\{a_n\}\) is a bounded sequence if it is bounded above and bounded below.

If a sequence is not bounded, it is an unbounded sequence.

front: What is the relationship between convergent and bounded sequences?
back: If a sequence \(\{a_n\}\) converges, then it is bounded.

A sequence \(\{a_n\}\) is increasing for all \(n \ge n_0\) if

\[ a_n \le a_{n+1} \text{ for all } n \ge n_0. \]

A sequence \(\{a_n\}\) is decreasing for all \(n \ge n_0\) if

\[ a_n \ge a_{n+1} \text{ for all } n \ge n_0. \]

A sequence \(\{a_n\}\) is a monotone sequence for all \(n \ge n_0\) if it is increasing for all \(n \ge n_0\) or decreasing for all \(n \ge n_0\).
If \(\{a_n\}\) is a bounded sequence and there exists a positive integer \(n_0\) such that \(\{a_n\}\) is monotone for all \(n \ge n_0\), then \(\{a_n\}\) converges.

An infinite series is a sum of the terms of an infinite sequnce \(a_n\):

\[ \sum_{n=1}^{\infty} a_n = a_1 + a_2 + a_3 + \ldots \]

The harmonic series is an infinite series of the following form

\[ \sum_{n=1}^{\infty} \frac{1}{n} \]

The harmonic series is a special case of the p-series with \(p = 1\).

front: What does the harmonic series converge to?
back: The harmonic series \(\sum_{n=1}^{\infty} \frac{1}{n}\) diverges to infinity.

The geometric series is an infinite series of the following form

\[ \sum_{n=0}^{\infty} a r^{n} = a + ar + ar^2 + ar^3 + \ldots \]

front: What does the geometric series converge to?
back: The geometric series \(\sum_{n=0}^{\infty} a r^{n}\) converges to \(\frac{a}{1 - r}\) if \(|r| < 1\), otherwise it diverges.

The p-series series is an infinite series of the following form

\[ \sum_{n=1}^{\infty} \frac{1}{n^p} = \frac{1}{1^p} + \frac{1}{2^p} + \frac{1}{3^p} + \ldots \]
The p-series \(\sum_{n=1}^{\infty} \frac{1}{n^p}\) converges if \(p > 1\), otherwise it diverges.

The telescoping series is an infinite series of the following form

\[ \sum_{n=1}^{\infty} a_n - a_{n+1}. \]

In other words, the telescoping series is a series in which most of the terms cancel in each of the partial sums, leaving only some of the first terms and some of the last terms.

front: What are the algebraic properties of convergent series?
back:
Let \(\sum_{n=1}^{\infty} a_n\) and \(\sum_{n=1}^{\infty} b_n\) be convergent series. Then the following algebraic properties hold.

  • Sum Rule: The series \(\sum_{n=1}^{\infty} (a_n + b_n)\) converges and \(\sum_{n=1}^{\infty} (a_n + b_n) = \sum_{n=1}^{\infty} a_n + \sum_{n=1}^{\infty} b_n\).

  • Difference Rule: The series \(\sum_{n=1}^{\infty} (a_n - b_n)\) converges and \(\sum_{n=1}^{\infty} (a_n - b_n) = \sum_{n=1}^{\infty} a_n - \sum_{n=1}^{\infty} b_n\).

  • Constant Multiple Rule: For any real number \(c\), the series \(\sum_{n=1}^{\infty} c a_n\) converges and \(\sum_{n=1}^{\infty} c a_n = c \sum_{n=1}^{\infty} a_n\).

front: What is the divergence test for a series?
back:
Consider the sequence \(a_n\). If \(\lim_{n \to \infty} a_n \neq 0\) or \(\lim_{n \to \infty} a_n\) does not exist, then the series \(\sum_{n=1}^{\infty} a_n\) diverges.

The converse is not true. That is, if \(\lim_{n \to \infty} a_n = 0\), we cannot make any conclusion about the convergence of \(\sum_{n=1}^{\infty} a_n\).

Suppose \(\sum_{n = 0}^{\infty} a_n\) is a series with positive terms \(a_n\). Suppose there exists a function \(f\) and a positive integer \(N\) such that the following three conditions are satisfied:

  • \(f\) is continuous,

  • \(f\) is decreasing, and

  • \(f(n) = a_n\) for all integers \(n \ge N\).

Then \(\sum_{n=1}^{\infty} a_n\) and \(\int_{N}^{\infty} f(x) \, dx\) both converge or both diverge.

Although convergence of the integral implies convergence of the related series, it does not imply that the value of the integral and the series are the same.

front: How to estimate the remainder of a series?
back: TODO

Suppose there exists an integer \(N\) such that \(0 \le a_n \le b_n\) for all \(n \ge N\). If \(\sum_{n=1}^{\infty} b_n\) converges, then \(\sum_{n=1}^{\infty} a_n\) converges.

Suppose there exists an integer \(N\) such that \(a_n \ge b_n \ge 0\) for all \(n \ge N\). If \(\sum_{n=1}^{\infty} b_n\) diverges, then \(\sum_{n=1}^{\infty} a_n\) diverges.

TODO Add an example.

Let \(a_n\), \(b_n \ge 0\) for all \(n \ge 1\).

If \(\lim_{n \to \infty} a_n/b_n = L \ne 0\), then \(\sum_{n=1}^{\infty} a_n\) and \(\sum_{n=1}^{\infty} b_n\) both converge or both diverge.

If \(\lim_{n \to \infty} a_n/b_n = 0\) and \(\sum_{n=1}^{\infty} b_n\) converges, then \(\sum_{n=1}^{\infty} a_n\) converges.

If \(\lim_{n \to \infty} a_n/b_n = \infty\) and \(\sum_{n=1}^{\infty} b_n\) diverges, then \(\sum_{n=1}^{\infty} a_n\) diverges.

TODO Add an example.

The alternating series is a sum of the terms of an infinite sequnce \(a_n\) whose terms alternate between positive and negative values:

\[ \sum_{n=1}^{\infty} (-1)^{n+1} a_n = a_1 - a_2 + a_3 - \ldots \]

or

\[ \sum_{n=1}^{\infty} (-1)^{n} a_n = - a_1 + a_2 - a_3 + \ldots \]

An alternating series of the form \(\sum_{n=1}^{\infty} (-1)^{n+1} \, a_n\) or \(\sum_{n=1}^{\infty} (-1)^{n} \, a_n\) converges if \(0 < a_{n+1} \le a_n\) for all \(n \ge 1\) and \(\lim_{n \to \infty} a_n = 0\).

TODO Add an example.

front: What is the relationship between absolute and conditional convergence?
back:
A series \(\sum_{n=1}^{\infty} a_n\) exhibits absolute convergence if \(\sum_{n=1}^{\infty} |a_n|\) converges.

A series \(\sum_{n=1}^{\infty} a_n\) exhibits conditional convergence if \(\sum_{n=1}^{\infty} a_n\) converges but \(\sum_{n=1}^{\infty} |a_n|\) diverges.

If \(\sum_{n=1}^{\infty} |a_n|\) converges, then \(\sum_{n=1}^{\infty} a_n\) converges.

Consider the series \(\sum_{n=1}^{\infty} a_n\) with nonzero terms. Let

\[ \rho = \lim_{n \to \infty} \left| \frac{a_{n+1}}{a_n} \right| \]

  • If \(0 \le \rho < 1\), then \(\sum_{n=1}^{\infty} a_n\) converges absolutely.

  • If \(\rho > 1\) or \(\rho = \infty\), then \(\sum_{n=1}^{\infty} a_n\) diverges.

  • If \(\rho = 1\), the test does not provide any information.

TODO Add an example.

Consider the series \(\sum_{n=1}^{\infty} a_n\). Let

\[ \rho = \lim_{n \to \infty} \sqrt[n]{|a_n|} \]

  • If \(0 \le \rho < 1\), then \(\sum_{n=1}^{\infty} a_n\) converges absolutely.

  • If \(\rho > 1\) or \(\rho = \infty\), then \(\sum_{n=1}^{\infty} a_n\) diverges.

  • If \(\rho = 1\), the test does not provide any information.

TODO Add an example.

The power series centered at \(x = 0\) is an infinite series of the following form

\[ \sum_{n=0}^{\infty} c_n x^n = c_0 + c_1 x + c_2 x^2 + \ldots \]

The power series centered at \(x = a\) is an infinite series of the following form

\[ \sum_{n=0}^{\infty} c_n (x - a)^n = c_0 + c_1 (x - a) + c_2 (x - a)^2 + \ldots \]

where \(x\) is a variable and the coefficients \(c_n\) are constants.

front: What are the convergence properties of a power series?
back:
Consider the power series \(\sum_{n=0}^{\infty} c_n (x - a)^n\). The series satisfies exactly one of the following properties:

  • The series converges at \(x=a\) and diverges for all \(x \ne a\).

  • The series converges for all real numbers \(x\).

  • There exists a real number \(R>0\) such that the series converges if \(|x − a| < R\) and diverges if \(|x − a| > R\). At the values \(x\) where \(|x − a| = R\), the series may converge or diverge.

front: What is the definition of the Laplace transform?
back:
The Laplace transform of a function \(f(t)\) is a function \(F(s)\) defined as

\[ F(s) = \mathscr{L}\{f\} = \int_0^\infty e^{-st} f(t) \, dt \]

where \(f(t)\) is a function of exponential order defined for all \(t \ge 0\).

front: What is the first translation or shifting property of the Laplace transform?
back:
If \(f(t)\) has the transform \(F(s)\) then

\[ \mathscr{L}\{e^{ct} f(t)\} = F(s - c) \] \[ \mathscr{L}^{-1}\{F(s - c)\} = e^{ct} f(t) \]

Example:

Since

\[ \mathscr{L}\{ \cos 2t \} = \frac{s}{s^2 + 4} \]

we have

\[ \mathscr{L}\{ e^{3t} \cos 2t \} = F(s - 3) = \frac{(s - 3)}{(s - 3)^2 + 4} \]

front: What is the second translation or shifting property of the Laplace transform?
back:
If \(f(t)\) has the transform \(F(s)\) then

\[ \mathscr{L}\{f(t - c) \, u(t - c)\} = e^{-cs} F(s) \] \[ \mathscr{L}^{-1}\{e^{-cs} F(s)\} = f(t - c) \, u(t - c) \]

where \(u(t - c)\) is the unit step function, which is defined as

\[ u(t - c) = \left\{ \begin{array}{ll} 1 & t \ge c \\ 0 & t < c \end{array} \right. \]

Example:

Since

\[ \mathscr{L}\{ t^3 \} = \frac{6}{s^4} \]

we have

\[ \mathscr{L}\{ f(t - 2) \, u(t - 2) \} = e^{-2s} F(s) = e^{-2s} \frac{6}{s^4} \]

front: What is the change of scale property of the Laplace transform?
back:
If \(f(t)\) has the transform \(F(s)\) then

\[ \mathscr{L}\{ f(ct) \} = \frac{1}{c} F \left( \frac{s}{c} \right) \] \[ \mathscr{L}^{-1} \left\{ \frac{1}{c} F \left( \frac{s}{c} \right) \right\} = f(ct) \]

Example:

Since

\[ \mathscr{L}\{ \sin t \} = \frac{1}{s^2 + 1} \]

we have

\[ \mathscr{L}\{ \sin 3t \} = \frac{1}{3} F \left( \frac{s}{3} \right) = \frac{1}{3} \frac{1}{(s/3)^2 + 1} = \frac{3}{s^2 + 9} \]

front: What is the unit step function \(u(t - c)\)?
back:
The unit step function (Heaviside function) \(u(t - c)\) is defined as

\[ u(t - c) = \left\{ \begin{array}{ll} 1 & t \ge c \\ 0 & t < c \end{array} \right. \]

front: What is the effect of multiplying by the unit step function \(u(t - c)\)?
back:
Let \(f(t) = 0\) for all \(t < 0\).

  • \(f(t) u(t - c)\) with \(c > 0\) is \(f(t)\) switched on at the point \(c\).
  • \(f(t - c) u(t - c)\) with \(c > 0\) is \(f(t)\) shifted (translated) to the right by the amount \(c\).

front: What is the unit impulse function \(\delta(t - c)\)?
back:
The unit impulse function (Dirac delta function) \(\delta(t - c)\) is a function that has the following properties.

Infinite at the origin \(c\), zero everywhere else:

\[ \delta(t - c) = \left\{ \begin{array}{ll} \infty & t = c \\ 0 & t \ne c \end{array} \right. \]

Area of unity:

\[ \int_0^\infty \delta (t - c) \, dt = 1 \]

Shifting or sampling property:

\[ \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} f(t) \delta (t - c) \, dt = f(c) \]

The unit impulse function is technically not a function but a generalized function or distribution.

front: What is the derivative of the unit step function?
back:
The derivative of the unit step function (Heaviside function) is the unit impulse function (Dirac delta function);

\[ \frac{d}{dt} u(t) = \delta(t) \]
\[ a^x \ln a \]
\[ \frac{1}{x \ln b} \]

\[ \cos x \]

Compare with

\[ \begin{align*} \frac{d}{dx} ( \sin x ) &= \cos x \\ \frac{d}{dx} ( \cos x ) &= - \sin x \\ \frac{d}{dx} ( \sinh x ) &= \cosh x \\ \frac{d}{dx} ( \cosh x ) &= \sinh x \end{align*} \]

\[ - \sin x \]

Compare with

\[ \begin{align*} \frac{d}{dx} ( \sin x ) &= \cos x \\ \frac{d}{dx} ( \cos x ) &= - \sin x \\ \frac{d}{dx} ( \sinh x ) &= \cosh x \\ \frac{d}{dx} ( \cosh x ) &= \sinh x \end{align*} \]

\[ \sec^2 x \]

Compare with

\[ \begin{align*} \frac{d}{dx} ( \tan x ) &= \sec^2 x \\ \frac{d}{dx} ( \cot x ) &= - \csc^2 x \\ \frac{d}{dx} ( \tanh x ) &= \text{sech}^2 \, x \\ \frac{d}{dx} ( \coth x ) &= - \text{csch}^2 \, x \end{align*} \]

\[ - \csc^2 x \]

Compare with

\[ \begin{align*} \frac{d}{dx} ( \tan x ) &= \sec^2 x \\ \frac{d}{dx} ( \cot x ) &= - \csc^2 x \\ \frac{d}{dx} ( \tanh x ) &= \text{sech}^2 \, x \\ \frac{d}{dx} ( \coth x ) &= - \text{csch}^2 \, x \end{align*} \]

\[ \sec x \tan x \]

Compare with

\[ \begin{align*} \frac{d}{dx} ( \sec x ) &= \sec x \tan x \\ \frac{d}{dx} ( \csc x ) &= - \csc x \cot x \\ \frac{d}{dx} ( \text{sech} \, x ) &= - \text{sech} \, x \tanh x \\ \frac{d}{dx} ( \text{csch} \, x ) &= - \text{csch} \, x \coth x \end{align*} \]

\[ - \csc x \cot x \]

Compare with

\[ \begin{align*} \frac{d}{dx} ( \sec x ) &= \sec x \tan x \\ \frac{d}{dx} ( \csc x ) &= - \csc x \cot x \\ \frac{d}{dx} ( \text{sech} \, x ) &= - \text{sech} \, x \tanh x \\ \frac{d}{dx} ( \text{csch} \, x ) &= - \text{csch} \, x \coth x \end{align*} \]

\[ \frac{1}{\sqrt{1 - x^2}} \]

Compare with

\[ \begin{align*} \frac{d}{dx} ( \sin^{-1} x ) &= \frac{1}{\sqrt{1 - x^2}} \\ \frac{d}{dx} ( \cos^{-1} x ) &= \frac{-1}{\sqrt{1 - x^2}} \\ \frac{d}{dx} ( \sinh^{-1} x ) &= \frac{1}{\sqrt{x^2 + 1}} \\ \frac{d}{dx} ( \cosh^{-1} x ) &= \frac{1}{\sqrt{x^2 - 1}}, \quad (x > 1) \end{align*} \]

\[ \frac{-1}{\sqrt{1 - x^2}} \]

Compare with

\[ \begin{align*} \frac{d}{dx} ( \sin^{-1} x ) &= \frac{1}{\sqrt{1 - x^2}} \\ \frac{d}{dx} ( \cos^{-1} x ) &= \frac{-1}{\sqrt{1 - x^2}} \\ \frac{d}{dx} ( \sinh^{-1} x ) &= \frac{1}{\sqrt{x^2 + 1}} \\ \frac{d}{dx} ( \cosh^{-1} x ) &= \frac{1}{\sqrt{x^2 - 1}}, \quad (x > 1) \end{align*} \]

\[ \frac{1}{1 + x^2} \]

Compare with

\[ \begin{align*} \frac{d}{dx} ( \tan^{-1} x ) &= \frac{1}{1 + x^2} \\ \frac{d}{dx} ( \cot^{-1} x ) &= \frac{-1}{1 + x^2} \\ \frac{d}{dx} ( \tanh^{-1} x ) &= \frac{1}{1 - x^2}, \quad (|x| < 1) \\ \frac{d}{dx} ( \coth^{-1} x ) &= \frac{1}{1 - x^2}, \quad (|x| > 1) \end{align*} \]

\[ \frac{-1}{1 + x^2} \]

Compare with

\[ \begin{align*} \frac{d}{dx} ( \tan^{-1} x ) &= \frac{1}{1 + x^2} \\ \frac{d}{dx} ( \cot^{-1} x ) &= \frac{-1}{1 + x^2} \\ \frac{d}{dx} ( \tanh^{-1} x ) &= \frac{1}{1 - x^2}, \quad (|x| < 1) \\ \frac{d}{dx} ( \coth^{-1} x ) &= \frac{1}{1 - x^2}, \quad (|x| > 1) \end{align*} \]

\[ \frac{1}{|x| \sqrt{x^2 - 1}} \]

Compare with

\[ \begin{align*} \frac{d}{dx} ( \sec^{-1} x ) &= \frac{1}{|x| \sqrt{x^2 - 1}} \\ \frac{d}{dx} ( \csc^{-1} x ) &= \frac{-1}{|x| \sqrt{x^2 - 1}} \\ \frac{d}{dx} ( \text{sech}^{-1} \, x ) &= \frac{-1}{x \sqrt{1 - x^2}}, \quad (0 < x < 1) \\ \frac{d}{dx} ( \text{csch}^{-1} \, x ) &= \frac{-1}{|x| \sqrt{1 + x^2}}, \quad (x \neq 0) \end{align*} \]

\[ \frac{-1}{|x| \sqrt{x^2 - 1}} \]

Compare with

\[ \begin{align*} \frac{d}{dx} ( \sec^{-1} x ) &= \frac{1}{|x| \sqrt{x^2 - 1}} \\ \frac{d}{dx} ( \csc^{-1} x ) &= \frac{-1}{|x| \sqrt{x^2 - 1}} \\ \frac{d}{dx} ( \text{sech}^{-1} \, x ) &= \frac{-1}{x \sqrt{1 - x^2}}, \quad (0 < x < 1) \\ \frac{d}{dx} ( \text{csch}^{-1} \, x ) &= \frac{-1}{|x| \sqrt{1 + x^2}}, \quad (x \neq 0) \end{align*} \]

\[ \cosh x \]

Compare with

\[ \begin{align*} \frac{d}{dx} ( \sin x ) &= \cos x \\ \frac{d}{dx} ( \cos x ) &= - \sin x \\ \frac{d}{dx} ( \sinh x ) &= \cosh x \\ \frac{d}{dx} ( \cosh x ) &= \sinh x \end{align*} \]

\[ \frac{1}{\sqrt{x^2 - 1}}, \quad (x > 1) \]

\[ \begin{align*} \frac{d}{dx} ( \sin^{-1} x ) &= \frac{1}{\sqrt{1 - x^2}} \\ \frac{d}{dx} ( \cos^{-1} x ) &= \frac{-1}{\sqrt{1 - x^2}} \\ \frac{d}{dx} ( \sinh^{-1} x ) &= \frac{1}{\sqrt{x^2 + 1}} \\ \frac{d}{dx} ( \cosh^{-1} x ) &= \frac{1}{\sqrt{x^2 - 1}}, \quad (x > 1) \end{align*} \]

\[ \frac{1}{1 - x^2}, \quad (|x| < 1) \]

Compare with

\[ \begin{align*} \frac{d}{dx} ( \tan^{-1} x ) &= \frac{1}{1 + x^2} \\ \frac{d}{dx} ( \cot^{-1} x ) &= \frac{-1}{1 + x^2} \\ \frac{d}{dx} ( \tanh^{-1} x ) &= \frac{1}{1 - x^2}, \quad (|x| < 1) \\ \frac{d}{dx} ( \coth^{-1} x ) &= \frac{1}{1 - x^2}, \quad (|x| > 1) \end{align*} \]

\[ \frac{1}{1 - x^2}, \quad (|x| > 1) \]

\[ \frac{-1}{x \sqrt{1 - x^2}}, \quad (0 < x < 1) \]

\[ \begin{align*} \frac{d}{dx} ( \sec^{-1} x ) &= \frac{1}{|x| \sqrt{x^2 - 1}} \\ \frac{d}{dx} ( \csc^{-1} x ) &= \frac{-1}{|x| \sqrt{x^2 - 1}} \\ \frac{d}{dx} ( \text{sech}^{-1} \, x ) &= \frac{-1}{x \sqrt{1 - x^2}}, \quad (0 < x < 1) \\ \frac{d}{dx} ( \text{csch}^{-1} \, x ) &= \frac{-1}{|x| \sqrt{1 + x^2}}, \quad (x \neq 0) \end{align*} \]

\[ \frac{-1}{|x| \sqrt{1 + x^2}}, \quad (x \neq 0) \]

\[ \begin{align*} \frac{d}{dx} ( \sec^{-1} x ) &= \frac{1}{|x| \sqrt{x^2 - 1}} \\ \frac{d}{dx} ( \csc^{-1} x ) &= \frac{-1}{|x| \sqrt{x^2 - 1}} \\ \frac{d}{dx} ( \text{sech}^{-1} \, x ) &= \frac{-1}{x \sqrt{1 - x^2}}, \quad (0 < x < 1) \\ \frac{d}{dx} ( \text{csch}^{-1} \, x ) &= \frac{-1}{|x| \sqrt{1 + x^2}}, \quad (x \neq 0) \end{align*} \]

If

\[ a x^2 + b x + c = 0 \]

then

\[ x = \frac{-b \pm \sqrt{b^2 - 4ac}}{2a} \]
